title: 107_hr781
content: The Act may be cited as the "Paycheck Fairness Act" and references amendments to the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. The Congress finds that women earn significantly lower pay than men for equal work, leading to wage depression for working families and hindering the optimal use of labor resources. The Congress finds that unequal pay for women hinders labor resources, burdens commerce, leads to unfair competition, and may violate workers' rights based on sex. Artificial barriers to wage discrimination based on sex persist despite laws like the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 and the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Removing these barriers would benefit the economy, reduce women's reliance on public assistance, promote family stability, and address past discrimination effects. The Equal Pay Act of 1963 aims to address past discrimination effects and ensure equal protection for workers based on sex in the private sector. Increased information and effective remedies will help women enforce their rights to equal pay for equal work. Certain employers have made strides in eradicating unfair pay disparities in the workplace, and their achievements should be recognized. SEC. 3. ENHANCED ENFORCEMENT OF EQUAL PAY REQUIREMENTS. Section 6(d)(1) (29 U.S.C. 206(d)(1)) is amended to allow for a differential based on factors such as education, training, or experience, as long as it is job-related or furthers a legitimate business purpose. The amended Section 6(d)(1) allows for a differential in wages based on factors like education, training, or experience, as long as it serves a legitimate business purpose. Employers must demonstrate that alternative practices were considered, the factor was reasonably applied, and any wage differentials are not the result of sex discrimination. The text discusses amendments to various sections of the labor law, including provisions related to wage reductions, application of subsections to job applicants, elimination of establishment requirements, and a nonretaliation provision. The text discusses amendments to labor law, including protections for employees and applicants regarding wage discussions and nonretaliation. Enhanced penalties are also outlined for employers violating these provisions. The text outlines amendments to labor law, including enhanced penalties for employers violating provisions related to wage discussions and nonretaliation. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs will provide training on wage discrimination, funded under section 9(b). The Secretary of Labor conducts studies and provides information to address pay disparities between men and women by promoting research, publishing findings, sponsoring educational programs, and providing information to various organizations. The Secretary of Labor addresses pay disparities by engaging with organizations, promoting achievements, and convening a national summit to discuss solutions. Additionally, there is a technical assistance and employer recognition program established. The Secretary of Labor will develop guidelines for employers to evaluate job categories based on objective criteria to compare wages and eliminate unfair pay disparities between occupations traditionally dominated by men or women. The Secretary of Labor will establish guidelines for employers to evaluate job categories and adjust wage scales to reflect the real value of women's contributions in the workplace. Employers who voluntarily conduct job evaluations and adjust wages accordingly will be recognized for their efforts. The Secretary of Labor may provide technical assistance to employers for evaluating and adjusting wage scales to ensure fair pay for women compared to men. Additionally, the Secretary of Labor may make rules to implement this section. Establishment of National Award for Pay Equity in the Workplace. The Alexis Herman National Award for Pay Equity in the Workplace is established, with specific criteria for businesses to qualify for the award, including demonstrating efforts to eliminate pay disparities between men and women. The President or designated representative shall annually present the award to businesses meeting qualifications determined by the Secretary of Labor, with appropriate ceremonies. The term "business" includes corporations and partnerships. Entities eligible for an award include corporations, partnerships, professional associations, labor organizations, and similar business entities. Additionally, entities conducting education or training programs, as well as joint programs formed by a combination of eligible entities, are also eligible. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF PAY INFORMATION BY THE EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION. Section 709 of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 is amended to require the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to conduct a survey on employee pay data for enforcing laws against pay discrimination. The Commission will identify additional data collections to enhance enforcement and make rules for collecting pay information based on sex, race, and national origin of employees. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission will prioritize enhancing enforcement of laws against pay discrimination by considering factors like employer burdens, report frequency, data confidentiality, and effective data collection formats. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary to carry out this Act may be appropriated.
